msItem.title: IV. Sälam - hymn for Cyricus

explicit.span: ኦአምላከ፡ ቅዱስ፡ ቂርቆስ፡ ሰማዕት፡ መስተጋድል፡ በዝንቱ፡ ቃለ፡ ኪዳንከ፡ ወተአምሪከ፡ አድኅነኒ፡ ለገብርከ፡ ኃጥእ፡ ወአባሲ፡ ሀብተ፡ ሥላሴ፡ ሴ
ወለጸሐፌ፡ ገድልከኒ፡ አነ፡ ቀሲስ፡ ኃይለ፡ ኢየሱስ፡ ዘሰመዩኒ፡ ርእሰ፡ ደብር፡ ወሊቀ፡ ካህናት

foreign.span: Fol. 33ra, l.3: ... you take away the faintheartedness from your people. O God of saint Cyricus, martyr, (spiritual) combatant, with this word of your covenant and your miracles save me, your sinful and transgressor servant, Habtä Śǝllase and your maid ... and also the scribe of your Vita, me, qäsis Ḫaylä ˀIyäsus, whom they appointed head of the monastery and archpriest.

list.item: 9 The original structure of the quires cannot be established due to the poor condition of the Ms. It can be assumed as follows: I(9/fols. 1r-9v)

supportDesc.condition: The original sewing is destroyed; most of the threads are broken and some of the leaves are held together by means of recent crude stitches. Several leaves have stains in inner margins (esp. fols. 7v–16r) and a few others are affected by humidity (esp. fols. 29r–33r). Fol. 20 is partly mutilated, a part of the text is missing.

layout.ab: The number varies between 18 and 22 lines.
The upper line is written above the ruling.
The bottom line is written above the ruling.

list.item: five red and black dot colon (used throughout the Ms.).
II. Four dot asterisk (esp. fols. 2ra, l.16, 32vb, l.5);
nine dot asterisk (used throughout the Ms.);
“X” with dashes above and below (esp. fols. 20vb, l.10, 32vb, l.8)
III. Nine dot asterisks, with chains of black and red dots above and below (esp. fols. 23va, 24va, 28ra, 32vb, 33ra).
- The word Täʾamrihu is written in red on fol. 34v; a few other words, also in red, are written on the left side in the middle of the same folio.

binding.decoNote: Two wooden boards. Two pairs of sewing stations.

origin.origDate: Late 19th century. The Ms. was produced by the same scribe as Ms. MMA-006 which is dated to 1886/87 A.D.

projectDesc.p: Encoded according to TEI P5 Guidelines.

person.persName: Habtä Śǝllase is mentioned in the supplication. The same person is mentioned in the explicit of Text II (esp. fol. 28ra ls. 8-9) as the commissioner (the one who “caused [the book] to be written”). In most cases he appears associated with a female, “his maid”, whose name remains unknown: in some places it is not written and in some others it is washed out and replaced with a different name, Wälättä Yoḥannǝs (e.g., fols. 26ra, 26vb), in a recent hand.

revisionDesc.change: transformed from mycore to TEI P5
